BY ED SULLIVAN
On Monday, WJHU-AM will
begin broadcasting to the dorms,
the Rathskellar, and the SAC
offices. FM operations are
tentatively slated to begin in
February, 1979, according to
WJHU station manager Jud
French.
French also announced that
the station has been awarded a
construction permit from the
FCC, allowing it to make the
final installation of its FM
gear."The FM license will be
received after these operations
are completed and the station has
met with the FCC's "proof of
performance" technical
requirements, a matter described
by French as being "a mere
formality."
Entirely campus oriented,
WJHU-AM will try to strike a
balance between the talents of
the staff and the listening desires
of the Hopkins community. "We
want to please as many different
campus tastes as possible, "
Program Director Jody Patilla
said. Surveys are being used to
determine what the students
want to hear, and will guide the
development of future
programming at WJHU. Current
plans call for shows featuring

progressive rock and jazz during
the day, softer sounds over the
lunch hour, specialty shows,
radio drama, public affairs and
show music in the evening and
hard rock and classical jazz' late
at night. A specific schedule will
be announced shortly.
It is hoped that WJHU-AM will
one day be self-supporting.
Advertisements from such
national companies as Carling
Breweries and the Coca-Cola
corporation have been run in the
past, as well as spots for local
businesses. The daily audience

10,500 people.

And still another communications medium is struggling
to emerge., namely the proposed student magazine.
Wednesday night at the Student Council meeting, two of its
founders submitted a constitution for consideration. As
indicated by the proposed constitution and by the
statements of-its founders, the group has not yet arrived at
a satisfactorily specific conception of what it intends to
print.
And it needs to be specific, for there are things the
publication should not be. Good fictional pieces can be
printed in Ellipsis. Granted, Ellipsis provides pitifully little
space for undergraduate contribution, but the emphasis
should be on expanding the literary publication rather than
mixing creative work in with a magazine dealing primarily
with analysis and opinions on issues. Articles concerning
controversial topics here in the University can and should
be published in the News-Letter. The News-Letter has
always been and remains open for quality contributions on
any subject relating to Hopkins.
The group's draft charter reads in part, "The purpose of
this publication is to provide an in-depth examination of
present day issues, people, and ideas; to create a forum for
ulidergraduate opinion and controversy concerning the
University nad our society..."This passage holds out a hint
of the worthwhile function that a new student publication
could perform. Student opinions on issues of national and
international interest—that is the rightful role of such a
magazine. No other vehicle exists on this campus for the
expression of such opinions. But the magazine needs to
clarify and specify suc.h a role as its purpose before it can
proceed to publish its first issue.

Your editorial in the last issue
concerning the divestment
question evidenced no small
degree of confusion with regard
to the "reality" of the situation
in that troubled region. But
perhaps more importantly, it also
spoke to this reader (at least) of
an outmoded and cynical set of
perceptions.
It is unfortunate that you
couch your view of acceptable
protest towards South Africa and
its policies of apartheid in terms
of "tangible consequences,"potential to influence,"tactics,"
and "real effects," for these all
evade the essence of our (in the
sense of Hopkins') dilemma:
divestment is a distinctly ethical
and moral, rather than technical
question. Hence,"real" effects of
any action we might take to
injure the regime in South Africa
are not strictly relevant. You are
correct when you point out the'
ineffectual nature of divestment
on our part as a "tool". However,
even seen in this perspective, I
object to the utilitarian ethic
your position is seemingly
grounded in. We are not
policy-makers in Washington

with complex linkages and
sensitivities to ponder, and hence
are morally bound to obey
ethical imperatives--our position
is so much clearer.
The self-cleansing moral action
that is divestment has enormous
value (or shoud have) to
ourselves, and as such is an
enormously valuable symbol. It is
not, and indeed should not
become a "grandstand play".
Significantly, your choice of that
term--suitably colorful for its
overly simple context--only
serves to highlight the
shallowness of your position. The
notion that we are only bound to
obey the moral directives of our
conscience when an audience is
present--as suggested by your
'grandstand' imagery--is sad and
absurd. Of course, my position,
as well as that of a great many
others (even a few informed
people, Mr. Wile), is based on the
premise that divestment is the
only moral position available.
Your editorial was offensive
because it attacked the value of
moral symbolism, while your
position implied the verity of
non-divestment as a moral
symbol in its owl right.
(According to Mr. Wile,
divestment is distinctly immoral.)
That, gentlemen, is unacceptable
hypocrisy for the symbol of
student opinion.
And oh, yes: if your "real
Homewood world" agenda of
issues only encompasses various
campus putterings and
brouhahas, then where do you
get off discussing anything
vaguely significant, anyway?
J.G. Cherim

BY DAVID KAPLAN
War and its ramifications has been a topic much dealt
with by movie-makers ever since the first films were
created. Patton, Sands of Iwo Jima, and All Quiet on the
Western Front are all examples of some of great war
movies which have become a part of our culture. But
Black and White in Color is different. It is a film whichdeals with war and is yet not a war-movie. To an extent,
the battles, the violence and all the horrors of war are
represented, but Black and White in Color is not content
to sit back and soberly preach to us. Instead it makes war
seem all the more horrible by showing us its absurdit.
Black and White in Color is set in the West African
savannah. The date is late 1914 and the story centers on a
French trading village separated from a German garrison
by a shallow river. Unknown to both sides, World War I
has begun so the two colonies spend their time
"civilizing" the black natives -- the Germans through
military drilling and the French by stealing as much as
humanly possibly. The monotony of the situation is
quickly broken when the French receive some old
newspapers which indicate that the war has been in
progress for six months. "Patriotism" immediately seizes

DESPERATE LIVING
MISFITS

the spirit of these Frenchmen who plan a sneak attack
(with a volunteer native army) on the Germans.
It is here that the men who at first appear as merely a
collection of debauched and venal petit-imperialists reach
new levels of idiocy. It is not -enough that the priests
make their living by selling worthless religious artif act to
the natives or that the military commander orders his
black orderly to find him local girls. The ultimate
absurdity appears when this same lot of people begin to
see themselves as the last defenders of free France. In
fact, they are so confident in their military (and spiritual)
superiority that they begin the war with a picnic.
'Black and White in Color as well as being an attack on
war, is also a sharp attack on white imperialism and does
this with a great deal of wit. By showing us the
pretensiousness and the hypocrisy of the settlers and
juxtaposing this with the placid, unassuning quality of the
natives and the landscape, Director Jean-Jacques Annaud
shows us that imperialism is not only evil, but is also a
ridiculous manifestation of human vanity.
Indeed the only character in the filmwho is in any way
different is transformed by the mini-war from a pariah
into absolute and undisputed leader. Hubert Fresnoy, a
young man assigned to study the regional geography, is
the sole person to warn against launching an attack and is
ridiculed for it. However, it is he who emerges as the sole
competent man after the natives fighting for the French are
completely routed by the bettu-trained German natives.
It is at this point that the film begins to deal with the
issue of leadership. Fresnoy gathers the loose strands after
the defeat and begins to assume full authority. We see in
him as a man who has a justified sense of his own
superiority, but who also is impeccably polite. In fact,
Fresnoy becomes so aloof that we can see a kind of
"Palace Guard" evolving as he surrounds himself with a
native staff trained in making sure Fresnoy is left alone.
Black and White in Color received an Oscar as the Best
Foreign-Film of the year in 1977, and it deserves its
recognition. It explores weighty topics without being
overly weighty, and it is precisely because of this that the
effects on the viewer are extremely profound. We are
allowed to see for ourselves the contradictions and
paradoxes, and the final scene after the end of the war is
so beautifully absurd as to be a successful culmination of
all that has gone on before.

A major exhibition of works by artist Paul Klee will be
exhibited at The Baltimore Museum of Art beginning
September 24 and continuing through November 19. The
exhibition consists of sixty-seven of Klee's finest works,
including oils, water -colors, gouaches, prints and
drawings. One of the major artists of the early part of the
twentieth century, Klee has been termed outside of
Picasso, probably more imaginative and varied in his
technique and style than any oCier artist in the twentieth
century.
Paul Klee was one of this century's most prolific,
complex and subtle artists. His average yearly production
was between 250 and 300 works, and over his career he
has recorded nearly 9000 works. Throughout his life, Klee
explored materials and techniques, merging one medium
and method into another. As a young artist he was
primarily a illustrator/draftsman, very linear in his
orientation. However, upon returning from a short trip to
North Africa in 1914, he wrote in his diary, "Color
possesses me...color and I are one." From that point on,
Klee emerges as colorist, producing works such as Runner
at the Goal (1921), Red Balloon (1922) and In the
Current Six Thresholds (1929), all included in this
exhibition.
In addition, there is an exhibition of watercolors,
engravings and drawing by the American artist Winslow
Homer, continuing through November 5. The exhibition
explored Homer's career as an illustrator before and after
he turned to oil pointing. Homer's illustrations are
carefully composed, decidedly linear works marked by
strong contrasts between light and dark. For subject
matter, he consistently selected outdoor scenes of both
fashionable and rural life, and also produced a number of
works based on sketches made during numerous trips to
the Virginia front during the Civil War.

To the Editor,
Your editorial in the last issue
concerning the divestment
question evidenced no small
degree of confusion with regard
to the "reality" of the situation
in that troubled region. But
perhaps more importantly, it also
spoke to this reader (at least) of
an outmoded and cynical set of
perceptions.
It is unfortunate that you
couch your view of acceptable
protest towards South Africa and
its policies of apartheid in terms
of "tangible consequences,"potential to influence,"tactics,"
and "real effects," for these all
evade the essence of our (in the
sense of Hopkins') dilemma:
divestment is a distinctly ethical
and moral, rather than technical
question. Hence,"real" effects of
any action we might take to
injure the regime in South Africa
are not strictly relevant. You are
correct when you point out the'
ineffectual nature of divestment
on our part as a "tool". However,
even seen in this perspective, I
object to the utilitarian ethic
your position is seemingly
grounded in. We are not
policy-makers in Washington

with complex linkages and
sensitivities to ponder, and hence
are morally bound to obey
ethical imperatives--our position
is so much clearer.
The self-cleansing moral action
that is divestment has enormous
value (or shoud have) to
ourselves, and as such is an
enormously valuable symbol. It is
not, and indeed should not
become a "grandstand play".
Significantly, your choice of that
term--suitably colorful for its
overly simple context--only
serves to highlight the
shallowness of your position. The
notion that we are only bound to
obey the moral directives of our
conscience when an audience is
present--as suggested by your
'grandstand' imagery--is sad and
absurd. Of course, my position,
as well as that of a great many
others (even a few informed
people, Mr. Wile), is based on the
premise that divestment is the
only moral position available.
Your editorial was offensive
because it attacked the value of
moral symbolism, while your
position implied the verity of
non-divestment as a moral
symbol in its owl right.
(According to Mr. Wile,
divestment is distinctly immoral.)
That, gentlemen, is unacceptable
hypocrisy for the symbol of
student opinion.
And oh, yes: if your "real
Homewood world" agenda of
issues only encompasses various
campus putterings and
brouhahas, then where do you
get off discussing anything
vaguely significant, anyway?
J.G. Cherim

BY DAVID KAPLAN
War and its ramifications has been a topic much dealt
with by movie-makers ever since the first films were
created. Patton, Sands of Iwo Jima, and All Quiet on the
Western Front are all examples of some of great war
movies which have become a part of our culture. But
Black and White in Color is different. It is a film whichdeals with war and is yet not a war-movie. To an extent,
the battles, the violence and all the horrors of war are
represented, but Black and White in Color is not content
to sit back and soberly preach to us. Instead it makes war
seem all the more horrible by showing us its absurdit.
Black and White in Color is set in the West African
savannah. The date is late 1914 and the story centers on a
French trading village separated from a German garrison
by a shallow river. Unknown to both sides, World War I
has begun so the two colonies spend their time
"civilizing" the black natives -- the Germans through
military drilling and the French by stealing as much as
humanly possibly. The monotony of the situation is
quickly broken when the French receive some old
newspapers which indicate that the war has been in
progress for six months. "Patriotism" immediately seizes

DESPERATE LIVING
MISFITS

the spirit of these Frenchmen who plan a sneak attack
(with a volunteer native army) on the Germans.
It is here that the men who at first appear as merely a
collection of debauched and venal petit-imperialists reach
new levels of idiocy. It is not -enough that the priests
make their living by selling worthless religious artif act to
the natives or that the military commander orders his
black orderly to find him local girls. The ultimate
absurdity appears when this same lot of people begin to
see themselves as the last defenders of free France. In
fact, they are so confident in their military (and spiritual)
superiority that they begin the war with a picnic.
'Black and White in Color as well as being an attack on
war, is also a sharp attack on white imperialism and does
this with a great deal of wit. By showing us the
pretensiousness and the hypocrisy of the settlers and
juxtaposing this with the placid, unassuning quality of the
natives and the landscape, Director Jean-Jacques Annaud
shows us that imperialism is not only evil, but is also a
ridiculous manifestation of human vanity.
Indeed the only character in the filmwho is in any way
different is transformed by the mini-war from a pariah
into absolute and undisputed leader. Hubert Fresnoy, a
young man assigned to study the regional geography, is
the sole person to warn against launching an attack and is
ridiculed for it. However, it is he who emerges as the sole
competent man after the natives fighting for the French are
completely routed by the bettu-trained German natives.
It is at this point that the film begins to deal with the
issue of leadership. Fresnoy gathers the loose strands after
the defeat and begins to assume full authority. We see in
him as a man who has a justified sense of his own
superiority, but who also is impeccably polite. In fact,
Fresnoy becomes so aloof that we can see a kind of
"Palace Guard" evolving as he surrounds himself with a
native staff trained in making sure Fresnoy is left alone.
Black and White in Color received an Oscar as the Best
Foreign-Film of the year in 1977, and it deserves its
recognition. It explores weighty topics without being
overly weighty, and it is precisely because of this that the
effects on the viewer are extremely profound. We are
allowed to see for ourselves the contradictions and
paradoxes, and the final scene after the end of the war is
so beautifully absurd as to be a successful culmination of
all that has gone on before.

a lyrical structure that was rarely if ever employed during
the beginnings of rock and roll. The content of the lyrics
from many recent releases is autobiographical, concerning
itself with questions of personal survival and creativity.
Whereas once, rock was a rather simplistic idiom with
hardly any concerns except to perform, many artists who
have been around for countless years have suddenly
become aware of age and image, and have become worried
about what comes next. One of the best examples of this
fear is Jethro Tull's album of two years ago, Too Old to
Rock and Roll, Too Young to Die- if a rock artist
cannot boogie forever and is not ready to die, what
exactly is this intemediary state between music and death.
Unlike other artists, the physicality of rock and roll
makes it virtually impossible for a rock musician to
continue past a certain age. Unless the person is Satchel
Paige, and the predicament of the rock musician is not
unlike that of.an athlete. After a certain number of years,
the timing is off, the .fast ball is slow and the arm is weak
and painful; and it would seem impossible for Pete
Townshend to leap around and for Mick Jagger to swagger
his hips forever. For all rock artists, it seems that they will
eventually reach a point where they cannot go on
anymore and they must "retire". These autobiographical
questions have been explored most recently on albums by
the Kinks and the Strawbs, two mainstays of British rock.

Misfits, though, is an exploration into these questions of
survival, answers to which the Kinks never before
pursued. The lyrics express the struggle to retain their

A major exhibition of works by artist Paul Klee will be
exhibited at The Baltimore Museum of Art beginning
September 24 and continuing through November 19. The
exhibition consists of sixty-seven of Klee's finest works,
including oils, water -colors, gouaches, prints and
drawings. One of the major artists of the early part of the
twentieth century, Klee has been termed outside of
Picasso, probably more imaginative and varied in his
technique and style than any oCier artist in the twentieth
century.
Paul Klee was one of this century's most prolific,
complex and subtle artists. His average yearly production
was between 250 and 300 works, and over his career he
has recorded nearly 9000 works. Throughout his life, Klee
explored materials and techniques, merging one medium
and method into another. As a young artist he was
primarily a illustrator/draftsman, very linear in his
orientation. However, upon returning from a short trip to
North Africa in 1914, he wrote in his diary, "Color
possesses me...color and I are one." From that point on,
Klee emerges as colorist, producing works such as Runner
at the Goal (1921), Red Balloon (1922) and In the
Current Six Thresholds (1929), all included in this
exhibition.
In addition, there is an exhibition of watercolors,
engravings and drawing by the American artist Winslow
Homer, continuing through November 5. The exhibition
explored Homer's career as an illustrator before and after
he turned to oil pointing. Homer's illustrations are
carefully composed, decidedly linear works marked by
strong contrasts between light and dark. For subject
matter, he consistently selected outdoor scenes of both
fashionable and rural life, and also produced a number of
works based on sketches made during numerous trips to
the Virginia front during the Civil War.
